blue corn pancake + barbecued duck w/habanero chile - star anise sauce $15 [3/5]
*** this was an ok dish. not too big a fan of the sauce. i think they were trying to work with the concept of a peking duck pancake here but was a little off on the execution. sounds like it's been on the menu for years so there might be fans out there. i'm just not one of them.

tiger shrimp + <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> w/corn - cilantro sauce $16 [4.5/5]
*** the star of the meal. it's got a lot of rave reviews for good reason. it's on point visually, texture-wise, and most importantly, in flavor. 

new mexican spices <mark>New Mexican Spiced Pork Tenderloin Sandwich</mark> w/grilled red onion, arugula ancho chile mayonnaise + <mark>Southwestern Home Fries</mark> $16 [4/5]
*** the ancho chile mayonnaise was mmmgoot. the pork tenderloin had a tasty rub as well. great flavors.

overall a solid meal but i probably wouldn't prioritize mesa over other vegas favorites. now..... where do i go in california/nevada to eat the kind of stuff he cooks on iron chef? or anywhere really?

ate here twice, both meals were really good, service was stellar.  had the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> $18, delicious but very, very rich, heavy cream texture.  also enjoyed the ancho chili salmon $32, but would prefer wild salmon over atlantic.  the fish seemed a little oily and although the sauces made it pop, i wouldn't order it again.  the fundido goat cheese dip $16 was hard to scoop, it had hardened in the iron dish and i question whether it was actual goat cheese or a blend.  the chips were chips.  the mesa margaritas $14 each were very tart, but fresh tasting and generous with the tequila. the woman at the bar was not as friendly as the floor staff, but she may just have been having a bad day.  hopefully the tip we left her cheered her up.  it is a fabulous restaurant offering top notch entrees and drinks.  can't wait to try other items on the menu the next time we are in vegas.

i was very surprised that i really enjoyed dining in this restaurant. i am not a big bobby flay fan so i was a bit hesitant to dine here for the first time but i'm glad my friends and i finally did it! we tried this place for lunch and started with the most awesome complimentary bread basket that included this blue and yellow jalape\u00f1o corn bread that was to die for! for starters we ordered the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>- scrumptious is one word to describe it! this dish truly got my attention, bobby! we also ordered rough cut tuna nachos- so refreshing and yummy. for our main courses we ordered the southwestern spice chicken skewer-grilled just right. smoked shrimp tacos-very well seasoned and cooked to perfection not dry at all. <mark>New Mexican Spiced Pork Tenderloin Sandwich</mark>-a great panini type sandwich with fine dining quality. for desert we ordered the most amazing banana bread pudding that left me speechless coz all i want to do is savor and eat it! the service we had was great and our server was very attentive. ambiance has a very modern feel with lots of colored vase to reflect the southwestern theme of the place.
this restaurant is definitely a must try when in vegas!

was...  okay.  maybe it's because we live in socal and are exposed to those flavors often, but we found ourselves disappointed.  the margaritas were great and the sweet potato clam chowder was unique and well seasoned.  the blue <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> side was dry, odd for something steamed, the replacement was equally bad.  the meat was okay but nothing to write home about.  for the price point i expected more.  if i was at my local steak house paying half that the value would have been there.

bobby flay's over gordon ramsey's steak house.

came here for my birthday, they don't do any free dessert or anything. if you order a dessert they would put a candle on it though. 

bread basket ( free ) - super yummy ! we really like the blue corn muffin.. it's soft and taste way better than your regular corn bread. the waiter let us get another order of it for free. 

entrees -( grilled lamb porterhouse chops ) the best i ever had, seriously. i'm that one person that always order lamb and i can honestly say this was the place. my medium rare lamb was cooked perfectly.. not to rare either just perfect and ever bite had this explosion in my mouth. so mouth watering good, it also came with a blue <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>! how can a tamale be so soft and moist? ugh, i want to go back and order this again. 

boyfriend had the ( new mexican spice rubbed pork tenderloin, cooked medium ) so good, i took a bite of it and the pork was moist and juicy. i didn't know you could get pork medium i guess it's just the part of pork you're eating you can. it also came with a sweet potato tamale, sounds weird together but very good. make sure to take a bite of the pork with the tamale together... oh you won't regret it hahaha. 

dessert -  ( chocolate cajeta cake ) - wow, moist! seriously every dish is so moist hahaha. best cake ever, try it guys. it's warm chocolate cake with ice cream, who doesn't like that? 

overall everything was super delicious, service was good but not top notch. everything was really filling, i honestly thought the dishes were way bigger, but the photos in yelp are all lies hahaha it's actually really small but when you continue to eat you'll actually get really full but  even though you're full you can't say no to dessert hahaha. 

2 entrees - 1 dessert = $108 and some change, which is a really good price for our meal.

we are locals, and came down to the strip for a celebration dinner.  mesa grill books up, so reservations are essential.  we arrived at our appointed time and were immediately seated.  we had a nice view of the open kitchen and serving window, so it was easy to spot some of the popular dishes as we were contemplating our order. the assistant waiter promptly came over and offered water. then, the only hiccup of the evening.  it took 10 minutes for the waiter to stop by and greet us and take drink orders.  service after that was just fine.

for $240 (inclusive of tax and a 20% tip), our party of two had:

3 really great margaritas.  they have 3 different varieties.  i had the one that was described as part tart, part sweet.  it was pink in color. really good.

2 appetizers:  <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> and lobster tacos.  both were outstanding.  as others have stated, the tacos are small.  however, when paired with a complete multicourse meal, they are perfect.

2 entrees:  veal chop and lamb chop.  both came with a side tamale, so we didn't order extra sides.  the veal chop may have been the best i've ever had.  really delicious.  the lamb was very good, but not as outstanding as the veal chop.

1 desert:  shared the banana cream pudding.  it was good, but could have used a bit more banana flavor.

the atmosphere here can border on loud.  you are adjacent to the casino, and although the windows separating the restaurant from the casino are floor to ceiling, they have a louvered effect, so both sound, and sadly, cigarette smoke enter the restaurant.  the smoke is not too bad, but it is noticeable.

this was our second visit, the first being lunch.  would definitely return again.  just remember, for dinner especially, make a reservation!

delicious brunch!  everything was delicious. the margarita is to die for. appetizers of <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> and tuna nachos were delicious and started off the meal perfectly. shared a <mark>Green Chile Cheeseburger</mark> that was amazing and ended the the best banana pie dessert i've ever experienced. deconstructed, with crunchy elements, toffee and of course banana. absolutely amazing!! we will definitely return here on our next visit.

we were in vegas for a special occasion and chose mesa grill because of the southwestern menu and good reviews. we enjoy sharing small plates so we chose from the appetizers and side dishes. lobster tacos ($20 for 3 tiny tacos) were tasty but overpriced. "sofie's salad" was a major disappointment, anemic oxidized lettuce with canned beans and mealy chopped tomatoes, cold from refrigeration. blue <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> side dish was like dry cornbread stuffed into a corn husk. chile relleno and cauliflower gratin were the best dishes we tried but nothing special. i love coconut cake but mesa grill's version didn't have any coconut flavor, it really didn't taste like anything. the ambiance and service get 4 stars, the food 2 stars at best. a huge disappointment. was it a bad night for the kitchen ? that shouldn't happen at a high caliber restaurant in las vegas.

i love you bobby flay!

never had brunch this sexy and sophisticated! what a great place to dine when you don't want to wait for hours to get inside the bacchanal buffet or if you're simply looking for a great restaurant in vegas.

love the american southwest inspired interior. it's bright and colorful, but not obnoxious and has a non intimidating fine dining feel. food was amazing and very memorable. we came on a saturday brunch, and they serve traditional american brunch fare with a south-western twist. 

we had
-complimentary pastries -blue corn bread, mini jalapeno biscuits, coffee cake with butter on the side. everything was yummy!
-<mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> $18- everyone's fav so i had to get it. 4 pieces of tiger shrimp on a bed of housemade tamale with roasted garlic cream sauce on top. it was was mix of a bit sweet from the tamale and savory from the shrimp and garlic sauce. amazing. get it! 
-<mark>Blue Corn Buttermilk Waffle</mark> $14 - crispy on the outside, light and soft on the inside. the bluecorn gave it a nutty flavor to the waffle. it's different and i liked it. it also had had enough black berry syrup that's not too sweet and the creme fraiche on top to cuts the sweetness. so good!
<mark>Spicy Mango - Glazed Bacon</mark> $4.50- recommended by our server. 2 thick strip of their house cured bacon with mango glaze on top. wow! never thought of mango with bacon and it's delicious! 
-<mark>Mesa Burger</mark> $18- perfectly cooked beef patty, double cheddar and grille onion. so simple yet delicious. it came with <mark>Southwestern Home Fries</mark> (french fries with chili powder) and horseradish mustard dip. get it!

service was great. our server was very nice and attentive. the table next to us was actually very rude to our server, but he remained professional and killed them with kindness. i also asked if bobby ever comes to visit and he said about 3x a year since he is a very busy man.

sad to say that this was not an enjoyable dinner. we tried many items, and neither the service nor most of the items were even average.
first, there are at least 20 people working in the front of the restaurant, and not once did any of them smile ever. i watched the entire staff and they seemed distant at best.
ok so first the food. ordered nine dishes and only was was any good. blue <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>, chile releno, and cauliflower gratin all underflavored. the sweet potato casserole was marginal.
the <mark>Baby Romaine Salad</mark> was described to have <mark>Spicy Chorizo Sausage</mark>. only one dime sized slice appeared on the plate.
the lobster tacos were fantastic, although a very small portion for almost 20 bucks.
we arrived 20 minutes early for our reservation and the manager was reluctant to seat us even though the place was half empty. he originally said we'd have to wait until closer to the reservation time.
i came here 2 years ago and had a great dinner. (see prior review.) not sure what happened but it looks like the place is more touristy.
sad to have had this experience.

i had lunch here the other day and it was so good we went back for dinner tonight. dinner was even better! service is top notch and the food was amazing. for lunch we had <mark>Baby Romaine Salad</mark> with chorizo and homily croutons, <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>, and the best burger ever. for dinner we had salmon, <mark>Sophie's Chopped Salad</mark>, incredible pork tenderloin and cauliflower gratin. both times we sat at the bar and the service was great. every time i travel to vegas i go to mesa grill. highly recommend.

some reviews of mesa grill describe a relatively mediocre experience. maybe it's what they ordered.  maybe i am easy to please. but, we had the ultimate mexican food meal. you know how most mexican restaurants have a page on the menu for "combination" dinners. we decided we wanted to create the ultimate mexican restaurant combination dinner.  and we did! two of us ordered threes dishes each and shared. 
blue corn lobster tacos 
<mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> 
yucatan chicken skewers 
smoked chicken and black bean quesadilla
blue corn pancake
cornmeal crusted chile relleno
it would not be fair to compare this to any mexican restaurant food. every dish exploded with flavor combinations that were as good as anyone could expect food to taste. it's really hard to describe how unbelievable this meal was. to be honest, i would say that for a palate pleasing meal, this was probably as good as anything i have ever eaten anywhere. if this isn't my favorite dinner, it is in the top three. this dinner was orgasmic. (i know that sounds like hyperbole, but it was pretty close!)
great upscale restaurant in a classey location. must try the prime rib with the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>.

this place has been around for awhile but never tried and heard good things about it so decided to give it a shot.  we got seated near the kitchen so you can oversee the chefs grilling their steaks so it got a little warm in our area.  definitely recommend trying the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> - a little spicy kick to them but balanced by a yummy creamy sauce and sweet <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>.  the spice rubbed pork tenderloin was very tender and the sauce definitely has a kick to it.  the blue corn tortilla encrusted halibut that my mom had was really good - definitely recommend if you don't want to eat meat.  the fish was a good size and meat was flaky - the crust added a nice crunch and flavor to the overall dish.  my brother had the veal chops which came highly recommended by the waiter - they were definitely very tender and juicy.  enjoyed the bread basket as well with a variety of walnut bread and corn muffins!

had been here about 5 years ago for my bachelor party weekend. glad i went back, as that weekend is a little hazy. 

we showed up right during a rush without a reservation, but found seats at the bar. our bartender was great as he dealt with our indecisiveness. we ordered the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> and the lobster tacos for apps. the tamale was incredible. the tacos were just okay. for my main course, i ordered the rabbit and it was incredible.  i would definitely go back for another visit.

the atmosphere is charming and the service fantastic. we came for brunch and tried an assortment from the menu. the first thing i have to recommend is the shrimp and <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>. the spice was so superb and well blended. there were probably ten different flavors that came together in a perfect medley of taste perfection. we also sampled the goat cheese queso/fondue. it also was amazing however a little on the heavy side. for our entree we had the salmon which was divine with a side of the maple bacon. this is a top notch eating establishment. everyone should try this at least one time in their life.

the tiger shrimp and <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> gives me life! it was amazinggg! i also had the chocolate cajeta cake for dessert - it was the best chocolate cake i've ever had. it was so moist and so delicious! i'm definitely going back to try more stuff on their menu.

we stopped here because we wanted breakfast. i was immediately pleased by the pleasant and 'quick to please' wait staff. the servers make sure your drinks never go empty or even half full. i ordered spicy scramble which comes with ham and biscuits. i also ordered the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> appetizer which was so savory and had the best sauce; so delicious i could drink it. i've never heard of <mark>House Ground Hominy Grits</mark>, but i was raised eating hominy... this is so good, it reminds me of my happy childhood breakfasts with my grandmother. the bread basket was filled with sweet and spicy bite size treats. wonderful! very pleased.

me and my husband had dinner here at the time of opening, which was 5 pm. we arrived about 10 minutes early and had cocktails. i had a refreshing lime citrus martini while waiting and a couple minute prior to service, we were seated. 

for appetizers, we ordered the delicious <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> which had a beautiful balance of flavored. for dinner i had the <mark>Ancho Chile - Honey Glazed Salmon</mark> that was delicious but i have had salmon taste a bite better than what i had. there was not enough seasoning and the salmon was slightly over cooked. 

my husband had the grilled porterhouse lamb chops which he absolutely could not hush about. he just had so many good things to say about it from the sauce to the accompaniment dish of plantain tamale. he had said that if he were to visit again, this would be the meal on his mind without hesitation. 

we finished off with the crushed blueberry line tart which was a little to tart for my taste. i like subtle and balanced flavors so probably would have enjoyed it with maybe a bit of coconut milk. :)

excellent service, incredible food!! start with the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>!  we had the lobster out of the shell. may possibly be the best meal ever! i've never been a big bobby flay fan, but mesa truly won me over!!
pork tenderloins and <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> were soooooooo good! would definitely go back here again.
whatever you do, get the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>! amazing food and excellent service. went during restaurant week and was not disappointed.

this place has become one of my favorite restaurants here in town, the food is absolutely amazing!!!!! 
i am a big fan of bobby flay, and i have always admired his dishes!! he just puts together an amazing variety of flavors into his food, he just has that excellent mexican touch! and mesa grill is an example of all that! 
let me start by saying that the service is outstanding! our server joel was very helpful and knowledgeable, we took his reccomendations and we were not dissapointed at all. 
now lets get to best part of mesa grill, which of course is the food! from the appetizer to the dessert everything was absolutely delicious!!!! the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> is a must try appetizer...both of our main entrees were amazing as well! and the tres leches dessert that we had, wow!!  we will definitely keep coming back!

hands down one of the best places to eat on the strip!! i little pricey than your typical buffet options on the strip. however the flavor are amazing the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> was my favorite along with the <mark>Cactus Pear Iced Tea</mark>.

my wife and i took one of our best friends here for his birthday last weekend. located in caesar's palace, i've tried but never been able to eat here before do to the insane wait times. not a problem with reservations one month in advance - we were seated promptly. the restaurant is beautiful inside. the staff were friendly and the service was nearly perfect.

we split appetizers. the blue corn duck was very tasty. the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> was just ok. the rough cut tuna nachos was absolutely delicious. nothing was that spicy despite frequent warnings from our server while ordering.

our friend got the pork tenderloin and was happy. i had a bite of it and thought it was indeed excellent. i got the blue corn crusted halibut. good sized portion, flaky and delicious. my wife's filet minion was to her liking.

we all enjoyed our drinks; sidecar for our friend, cucumber something for the wife and i went with the margarita. my only complaint was that the margarita came in a martini glass and the portion was too small - i had three with my meal. in no way did i feel as though i had drank three margaritas. just saying...

for desert we split the banana cream cookie thing. totally forgettable, we didn't eat half of it.

bottom line: i'm glad we went and would be happy to eat here again. but, with all the other fine dining establishments available in vegas, probably wont'.

my buddies and i came here one weekend after reading staggering reviews. the food were tasty overall.  the best dish was the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>. the sauce was savory and spot on.
portions were a bit on the smaller portion scale for the $$$ prices on the menu so doing family style might not be ideal.

the only thing we didn't like was one of the sides - spinach rossito because of the cheese they put in made it very salty. the waiter was nice enough to replace it with mashed potato. the service was decent but they forgot to bring extra bowls even though they weren't too busy.

wonderful place at an affordable price.
had the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> and devoured it.
no tank top, casual but cool place to hang out.
excellent burgers, been here twice 
bathroom, a must see.
waiters are very attentive but when they hand you the bill they force you to pay 18 percent gratuity due to a large group, thumbs down on that. but then again, they don't know that i own a business and i tip generously.

mesa grill is definitely a restaurant you need to experience in las vegas. this bobby flay restaurant is located inside of caesars palace. the restaurant seating is an open spaced floor plan and has  a nice warm southwestern feel. we came here during restaurant week so  i was hesitant on how long the wait would be. to my surprise we got seated right away! instantly i was pleased as i am not a very patient person when it comes to waiting for a seat. 

my first dish i tried was the new mexican spice rubbed pork tenderloin with a bourbon and ancho chile sauce and a sweet potato tamale with crushed pecan butter. all i can say is heaven. it was amazing. i am always nervous to try pork dishes as it is my favorite type of meat and i hold it to a very high standard. this was the best pork dish i have ever had. tender, juicy and the mix of spices took me on a wild tasty ride! 

the next dish i tried was the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> with corn in a cilantro sauce. oh my goodness. i was blown away! the mix of the sweet corn, butter and cilantro sauce was paired so nicely with the shrimp that i ate the whole thing! i couldn't put the fork down it was just too delicious.  the shrimp was huge and the portion of this dish was perfect! i would have never paired shrimp with corn before but am looking forward to finding a way to make this recipe at home.

another dish i recommend is the <mark>Ancho Chile - Honey Glazed Salmon</mark> with spicy black bean sauce and roasted jalape\u00f1o crema. i was hesitant to order something with black bean sauce as i have never heard of anything like that before. i am glad i took the jump and tried something new! i was totally impressed with the flavors from the jalape\u00f1o crema, the salmon and the black bean sauce.

i had such a great experience my first time at mesa grill that i have been back numerous times since. when you visit las vegas make sure to make mesa grill a priority on your "to do" list. you will not be disappointed, i guarantee it!

see my full review here: http://corkedandporked.com/2015/03/23/bobby-flays-las-vegas-restaurant-mesa-grill/

i have been here a few times for dinner.  this was the first time i had lunch here.  we stared with the goat cheese queso fundido that was creamy and delish. the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> was probably the best thing we had.  the combination of the shrimp and corn, plus the corn sauce is really good.  great combo of flavors. the cornmeal crusted chile relleno is probably the most beautiful plate with gorgeous colors of the sauces.  it looked like a piece of art and it tasted really nice.  it is light, filled with a yummy cheese.  the shrimp tacos were very good.  the shrimp was tender and bursting with flavors and spices.  my friend had the salmon and loved it.  the salmon was flakey and perfectly cooked.  dessert was great.  we had a chocolate cake and and a pistachio cake that were both great.  the pistachio had a strawberry ice-cream and fresh berries.  the margaritas are really good, served on the rocks.

a wonderful "foodie' experience!  we shared 4 appetizers and dessert.  we were full and satisfied.  the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> was beyond flavorful... maybe just a little small.  the shrimp were medium size and only 4 of them.
we were seated at a small table for 2 even tho the  place was not very busy.  table very crowded.  two couples seated after us each got tables for 4.  guess we should have asked.  our waiter was missing in action alot and we had several people filling in.  
again, food full of flavors and fabulous.  wait staff not so much!

i can't believe this place was as empty as it was on a saturday afternoon. i'm guessing it gets busier at night, but i have no idea. the food was exceptional, and the service exemplary. 

instead of bread, they bring you a basket of little breads, muffins and pastries. we didn't eat all of them, but got them to give us a doggy bag for late night snacks. 

the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> was soooooo good i'm still dreaming about the sauces it came with. 5 star dish all the way!

we also got the tuna "nachos." these aren't really nachos - they give you small tortilla potato chips basically you use to scoop up the raw chunks of tuna and the two sauces it comes with - a habanero sauce that wasn't too spicy and an avocado crema.

also, we ordered the shrimp tacos. they were delicious - i don't know what bobby flay puts in those sauces (other than copious amounts of butter) but i can't get enough. the tortillas are unlike any i've had before, but they might just be the most perfect tortillas ever - soft and strong so that they don't fall apart. 

will be back for the <mark>Mesa Burger</mark> next time i'm in vegas.

the gf and i were looking to indulge in a proper lunch before leaving for our flight back to philly. so after checking out at caesars palace, we stopped by bobby flay's mesa grill. while the original nyc restaurant is now closed (he's got bar americain and the recently opened gato now), in vegas, the iron chef is still able to showcase the southwestern flavors and flair he's known for.

located a stone's throw away from the opulent omnia nightclub, mesa grill is sleekly designed with southwest elements and colors. 

bread service

bread service started us off with a nice variety of freshly baked sourdough, cranberry walnut, and a great blue and sweet corn muffin with a bit of jalapeno. nice.

goat cheese queso fundido [$16]
rajas, blistered serrano vinaigrette, blue corn tortilla strips

we had the goat cheese queso fundido, which was gorgeously creamy. it had some nice heat from the blistered serrano vinaigrette, which was accented by the roasted red and green chiles. the cilantro added a nicely fresh herbaceouness to each bite. the crispy blue corn tortilla strips were a great vessel to scoop up all the deliciousness.

tiger shrimp & <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> [$18]
corn, cilantro sauce

easily one of the best tamale's i've had, the creamy richness of the roasted garlic and sweet corn sauce on point. the tiger shrimp was supple, yet had good snap and the corn masa within was luxurious and not at all dry. the cilantro sprig helped to brighten up each bite. 

spicy chicken & <mark>Spicy Chicken  Sweet Potato Hash</mark> [$18]
poached eggs, green chile hollandaise

the gf went with the spicy chicken and <mark>Spicy Chicken  Sweet Potato Hash</mark> for her main. there was a great lusciousness to each bite, with some texture from the sweet potato and the moist chicken. the green chile hollandaise had a bit of heat to it, though very slight. the poached egg brought each bite over the top. 

cornmeal crusted chile relleno [$18]
roasted eggplant, manchego cheese, sweet red pepper sauce, balsamic vinegar

my cornmeal crusted chile relleno offered great texture from the cornmeal crust, which cracked open to reveal a creamy manchego malenge with well-roasted eggplant. the green and red sauces emblematic of bobby flay were on display here and not just for show. along with the sweet notes from the balsamic, these sauces helped to providing some acidic balance to each bite. 

overall, mesa grill was spot on in terms of execution and taste. i wouldn't hesitate to recommend stopping by, especially if you're looking for a glimpse into the flavors that are the foundation of iron chef bobby flay.

mesa grill, what a fabulous environment located in busy caesars palace. it's was busy but reservations got us right in no problem. server was great and they all help each other so your drink never sees the bottom of glass. 

my wife started off with a bowl of their famous <mark>Fresh Tomato Soup</mark>, i can't stand tomatoes but this was like a cooked salsa. it was surprisingly tasty. i ordered the roasted corn chowder which was offered for a limited time and let me tell you it was out of this world. next up was their famous <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>, i almost licked the plate clean.

for our entrees, my wife went with the chicken & black bean quesadillas. those were crazy good. i went with their famous spice rubbed pork tenderloin, it did not disappoint. cooked perfect with a spicy bbq sauce drizzled over it. i've had it before but tonight's was amazing. i highly recommend the side of corn & jalape\u00f1o that might just be the best thing in their menu.

dining at mesa grill was a split experience. we loved the food - we were initially served with a bread bowl which was really fresh and warm. we ordered <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> as our appetizer - which was the best dish of the evening. for the main course we ordered sixteen spice chicken and ancho chili. chicken was nice and moist but nothing spectacular; it came with mashed potatoes which is a whole other story - simply delicious. chili was amazing - the crust and the sauce were probably the best parts of the dish.

service in general was ok - glasses were filled with water regularly - we were checked on to see how our food was and such but.... it was my friends birthday and we asked the hostess to bring out a cake as a surprise towards the end (i was obviously going to pay for it). guess what - nothing! was really disappointed by such carelessness from such a big establishment especially when we went there only to celebrate someone's birthday! not sure we'll return after our experience.

being a huge fan of the food network, i knew i had to hit up bobby flay's restaurant since i was staying at caesars palace. caesar palace has tons of options but we decided to dine here for the night. 

i started with <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> with cilantro sauce. this thing was amazing. one of the best tamales i have ever eaten in my life. all the flavors sync up and its the best. its more on a pricey side from your $2 tamales but its life changing. 

i also ordered the steak but i thought it was okay. the roasted corn was pretty good and the double baked potatoes. 

all in all, i got to cross it off my list of restaurant i been wanting to try. service was really good too.

i want to be upfront and let everyone know i'm probably a little biased with this review. i watch a lot of food porn (food network) and bobby flay is king. 

went to mesa grill at 945pm for a late dinner. thought the waiters may be ready to go home but that wasn't the case at all. we had great service the entire meal. 

we stared with 2 <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>. 1 wasn't enough. 

i had the ribeye (sauces on the side). best sw steak i've had. my wife got the coffee rubbed filet also deadly. 

overall this was a great culinary experience and i'll be back.

went here for brunch with the fam bam. the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> was out of this world. the shrimp were very well seasoned, the tamale filling was slightly sweet and had corn for a nice texture contrast. as much as it pains me to give it a 5 star since bobby flay isn't my favorite person this restaurant definitely deserves it for the food, ambience and excellent service we got. price point is expected for being a signature restaurant.

can't stop raving about this place!  lots of things looked good, but i was told i specifically needed to try the steak.  ribeye was sold out (couple hrs before they closed on a monday night), so i got the ny strip steak.  the seasoning and the sear on the steak were just right, cooked to medium rare, and served with a circle comprised of 3 sauces.  one of the sauces had a little kick but lended a complexity to the flavor.  it was unlike any steak i've ever had before.  if you want a steak but possibly something different, i would highly recommend this place.  i could tasty salty and spicy among other things.

ny strip steak = 5/5
shrimp & <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> appetizer = 5/5 (big enough to share w/ a friend)
roasted corn side = 5/5 (couldn't begin to finish all of it, share a side w/ a friend)
complimentary bread and butter = 5/5 (several kinds of bread)
shell-off lobster = 4/5 (i tried my friend's entree and didn't have my own, so this is based on 1 bite really)
service = 5/5

with no microwave at my hotel, i made a point to finish the steak at the expense of leaving some of the other stuff behind.

i've eaten here twice in the last 3 days. i really enjoyed the food. the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> were amazing! i loved the rabbit and the lobster out of the shell. there drinks are good too. service was decent. i would definitely go back!

mesa grill at caesars palace in viva las vegas will make your toes curl! from 1 to 10, it's an 11! the service is impeccable and each dish will want you yearning for one last bite. great wine selection, tequilas and fantastic margaritas. be careful those margaritas will sneak up on you quickly. lobster tacos, rough cut tuna nachos, <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>, coffee rubbed filet and pork dishes are all can't miss. order a bunch and share as you don't want to miss any of these. bobby flay hits the mark and should be on anyone's list for culinary delight while in las vegas.

this review is based on a visit 04/21/2015 for lunch right at open (11am).  

seated immediately without reservation, which was great.  server provided recommendations without needing to be asked.  constant water refills when only partially empty.  great service overall.

items ordered:
- blue corn pancake w/ duck bbq -- this is my wife's absolute favorite item here, and it was ok but definitely not as good as in the past.  this alone is one of the primary reasons we keep coming back, so that was disappointing.
- tiger shrimp w/ <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> -- this was good, although there could have been more of it.  it's an appetizer though, so that's kinda the norm.
- entree - shrimp tacos w/ avocado, tomatillo, mango sauces, citrus cilantro slaw.  this was a suggestion from the waiter.  just average, nothing great.    would not order this again.
- entree - yucatan chicken skewers -- horribly disappointing. 3 tiny pieces of chicken with peanut chile aioli, with 2 tiny dried up tortillas.  i couldn't believe it was so bad.

seating is very close quarters, to the point that it's uncomfortable trying to have a conversation.  you are literally in the conversations of people next to you, and while that may be an attractive feature of a family-style restaurant, it's not appropriate in this location.  definite minus for that.

mesa grill has always been one of our "must-go" stops on previous trips.  we've been there twice before this visit, but both visits were for dinner.   this is the first time that the food was not stellar, and that's the only reason this is a 3-star review and not a 2.  price is not an issue, because it's pretty standard for vegas strip places and the food was always great previously and worth every penny.  we *might* go back next time we visit, but it's definitely off the "i can't leave vegas without going" list.

food, fiesta and fun!

a whole, fresh new take on mexican, texmex and southwestern cuisine.

not really new but for those who think mi pueblo or chipotle is good mexican cuisine this will be a treat!

we shared 4 entradas from <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>, pancake duck and queso fondido to lobster tacos and loved every one of them. 

servicio was excellente as were the cactus pear margaritas. 

highly recommend!!!

[this review is for the brunch menu.]

mesa - this restaurant has been staring me in the eye for ages and i finally got to take it on with great results.  

the menu is a southern tex-mex style and lots of style indeed.  dishes are flavorful and fairly bold in their interpretations of classic dishes you may be used to.  one of the early delights is the included bread basket with a lot of tasty choices.  my personal favorite was the blueberry scone and another really interesting bread concoction (not sure if it was a zucchini bread?)  my table ordered a variety of dishes from there (they also have a fairly robust wine list and margarita list as well along with a full bar menu) that ranged from <mark>Barbecued Lamb Cobb Salad</mark> to amazing looking waffles.  from the dishes i tried, i surprisingly loved the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> the most.  the presentation was not only very well done but the flavors of both the tamale and the well-spiced tiger shrimp hit the spot.   

my only small complaints were that some of the dishes didn't seem as strong as the others.  the house margarita (i believe called the patrida) was a little more hit-or-miss - not as sweet but not as flavorful as other margaritas i've had either.  the <mark>Spicy Chicken  Sweet Potato Hash</mark> also was a little more on the not-so-sure side.  i liked the presentation but the dish came out a little colder than expected and the <mark>Spicy Chicken  Sweet Potato Hash</mark> wasn't as flavorful.  perhaps an off day for the dish?  

service was excellent for sure (friendly, fun and keeping tabs on us regularly) and brunch on a saturday was surprisingly not that busy.  the decor has a fun fire theme throughout the entire restaurant that goes from the ceilings to the lighting - i really dug the theme.  

all-in-all, mesa is a fantastic restaurant stop and the brunch doesn't burn the wallet either.  a worthy check out.

this place never disappoints us.  at least 5 meals and everything tastes great.

this time they served our table their <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>...a nice 4 share on appetizers.  the queso fundido was outstanding.

my sister loved her lamb chops and i shared the lobster with my wife.

they pour stiff drinks and the service is attentive and professional.  great if you are seeing a show at caesars!

mesa grill provided an interesting and delicious variety of unique options.  we started with the lobster tacos and <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>. tacos had more heat than i prefer, but the texture was good.  

the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> were excellent. the plating was a little unexpected; this is not your typical tamale were the protein is cooked in the middle of the maza.  the maza is wrapped in a corn husk, steamed and sliced open.  the shrimp are prepared separately.  everything is swimming in a yummy corn sauce. not spicy at all.  big enough to serve as a stand alone meal. would definitely eat this again.

had the pork tenderloin for a main entree.  it was masterfully cooked.  i loved the combination of sauces - sweet with mild heat. the sweet potato "tamale" was ok.

we left stuffed.  excellent meal for our first night in vegas.

the best (although dangerous) margaritas! i loved the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>...and you can not go wrong with the lobster tacos.
i have enjoyed several visits...the service is always great.
again, the best margaritas...

great food , a bit pricey but worth the money.
my favorites are <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> and rib eyes steak.
 best i have ever had.
make sure that you have the reservation.

had a quick work dinner and this restaurant was recommended when asked for a place with flavor and great food. it delivered. had the shrimp and tamale appetizer which was delicious. shrimp was cooked well and layered in with a flavorful well seasoned and cooked <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> and sauce. also had the nectar margarita which was good. would have loved to have had a little more salt to cut the sweetness. 
for an entree i ordered the pork tenderloin that was seasoned and perfectly cooked but was definitely out shone by the accompanied tamale and roasted corn (side dish ). amazing flavor. service was great except for the host that could not have been more uptight.

i had to visit this place, as i do many bobby flay restaurants. i had to have the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> with tiger prawns, a staple there. i also have to try the roasted brussels sprouts with hazelnuts and he pesto cilantro mashed potatoes (try them before you judge!). i asked for a table close to the pass and hotline so i could watch the kitchen male their amazing dishes. the staff was extremely friendly and very attentive. it was one of my favorite meals of the week!

it was an easy choice to have dinner at mesa grill since we were staying at the caesars palace and the fact that it was owned by the chef bobby flay.   we arrived around 6 pm on a wednesday evening and seated promptly.  

we ordered <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>, coffee rubbed filet mignon, pork tenderloin and brussels sprout salad.   

the shrimp was cooked perfectly and the fresh tasting <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> was delicious.   the filet was very tender; however, it did not have much flavor.  actually after we added tobacco sauce and it tasted better. this was the first time we had medium rare park tenderloin and it tasted great.  the brussels sprout salad had lots of flavor and we loved it.  

my husband had two martinis with a few cheese stuffed olives for $38.  we thought it was pretty stiff.  

overall, it was a good dining experience.  will we return?  probably not.

a worth it stop when in vegas, heavy on southwestern flavors, you will enjoy bobby flay's menu ridiculously. his menu modernizes traditional southwestern dishes, pairing spicy and sweet wonderfully. 

located in caesar's palace, the decor is modern and bright with reds & yellows and an upscale but comfortable, intimate atmosphere. be prepared for a wait without a reservation.

bread basket: several varieties of warm fresh breads. the blue corn jalapeno muffins were a hit with this guy. asked the waiter to bring more asap. munched heavily on the asiago jalapeno bread as well.

<mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>: ($18) as the appetizer of the century i was more than happy to have ordered this. shrimp was cooked lovely and dusted with spicy, sweet flavors. a warm, soft tamale wrapped up lime cilantro & a chipotle aioli. nicely done sir, nicely done.

grilled lamb porterhouse chops: ($42) decadent, fall off the bone lamb. the serrano chili sauce adds some warmth to the bite, without making you sweat. not to overpower, a mint chimichurri adds a unique minty jalapeno aroma & character. 

i shall return.

came here last weekend for dinner. had reservations but still had to wait a little bit. 

as an appy, i had the tiger shrimp and <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>. definitely recommended, the sauce is very delicious and makes the shrimp taste even better. but the corn/maize that is leftover at the end is a bit weird.

i ordered the filet mignon medium rare and mash potatoes on the side. had them to have everything come out quick because i was kind of in a time crunch. i was assured by the server it will be okay. thankfully he was right.

the steak came out in a reasonable time and was medium rare like i ordered it. it was definitely delicious, but not sure if it can justify $50 usd. it should at least come with a side or two at that price. the mash potatoes were an extra $10 usd and there really wasn't anything special about it. the mash potatoes were average at best. 

overall the food was great, but it is definitely on the pricier end for me. but it is vegas after all. food speed and service was reasonable. i would recommend it to others, but hard to say with so many other options if i would come back.

i came to this place during my lunch break from a conference. i'm an avid food network binge watcher so my colleague and i decided to give this place a try since it was one of bobby flay's restaurants. we started off with the tiger shrimp and <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> and holy buddha was that a winner. the masa in the tamale was so creamy and the corn was so sweet and supple. you could definitely taste the hint of garlic as well. the tiger shrimp were cooked perfectly. i got the hot smoked salmon sandwich with the southwest french fries. the sandwich was the size of the state of nevada. so huge! it was a pretty tasty sandwich although i think it was a bit much. my colleague got the spicy chicken and <mark>Spicy Chicken  Sweet Potato Hash</mark>. the poached egg on top definitely sent it to another realm. it was a great brunch item. i'll definitely stop by this place when i come back to to caesars. 

my only gripe doesn't have to do with the food. being. a safety professional there for a conference pertaining to safety, the floors were ridiculously slippery and i gliding several times. the area by their girl is super greasy so watch your step!

party of 10 on saturday night, 6pm

service was great - he made sure to ask if we were going to a show, and we were.  so he kept us on time and ushered us out so we could get there on time.  

the best thing all night was the shrimp and <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> - that had great flavor and was a unique dish.  

we ordered several things off the menu but i had the lamb porterhouse chop - large serving, cooked medium rare.  tasty but didn't blow my mind.  friends ordered the tuna steak, rabbit and salmon dishes - all were ok.  for the price you pay, you're really just getting big portions and little on flavor, technique or originality.  

overall, it's a very expensive steakhouse.  mediocre, nothing terrible, nothing great.  given that there are so many good places in vegas to eat, i would not recommend spending your money on this one.

i'm surprised that i didn't hear more about this place before i visited because i thought it was great. 

both times i've eaten here i have opted for the new mexican spice rubbed tenderloin. i believe they boast this as one of their signature dishes and it's for good reason. the tenderloin has great chile spice flavor and is the most tender pork dish i've ever had. the sweet potato tamale on the side is the perfect pairing with the chile tenderloin. 

the bread basket served before the meal has a variety of breads and all are tasty. my favorite is the blue corn cornbread. the appetizer that sent my taste buds in a spiral was the tiger shrimp & <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>. the flavors in this appetizer are out of this world and the sauce is good enough to eat alone.

i had a heck of a time finding good restaurants in vegas. all the restaurants cheaper than this that i went to sucked. i was pleased with the things i ordered. everything in vegas is overpriced but this place didn't make me regret spending my money like so many others. <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> appetizer. 16 spice chicken (not for those who are sensitive to heat). eggplant chile relleno was good except i wasn't a big fan of the cornmeal batter.

we really enjoyed our brunch at mesa grill. we ordered the tuna tare tare nachos, <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> and the shrimp tacos. 

the complimentary bread basket was really tasty, and a great way to start the meal! the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> were out of this world. i have never tasted a tamale anywhere near as good as this dish was- it was amazing! the tuna tare tare nachos and <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> were good, but nothing outstanding! overall, we enjoyed our meal! make sure you order the tamales.

mesa grill is hit or miss depending on what you order here. i've had a mix of both hits & misses here and thankfully this visit was a hit.

this was a quick visit between my bar hopping and other eats this vegas trip. i told myself i had to stop in here since it's been a year or so since i last visited and i did just for an appetizer. if there's anything i truly enjoyed from my previous visit, it was the sweet potato tamale that came with my pork tenderloin which prompted me to try the tiger shrimp and <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> this time around.

this tamale was very flavorful...a perfect blend of sweet corn and garlic. the tiger shrimp were a nice size as well as delicious. $18 well spent for a quick snack and worth it.

if there's one thing i can say about mr. flay, he knows how to make some damn good tamales with any spin he throws on them. my taste buds love it which means this will most likely draw me back in for another visit.

snack 12/12/2015
dish_name: Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale

text:
when i heard bobby flay owned this joint, i knew i had to try.... i watch iron chef religiously and i believe it caused my expectations to be alittle too high. 

bread basket: (yes, i consider this a course) disappointing. i like my bread warm and fresh from the oven. these offerings were too cold to enjoy. 

appetizers: got the <mark>Baby Romaine Salad</mark>, gala apple salad, and the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>. i could have skipped all these dishes and saved more room for dessert. the tamale was good, but the flavors didn't have me singing to the high heavens... and the salads left much to be desired. the <mark>Baby Romaine Salad</mark> lacked dressing and the croutons were way too soggy. the apple salad was mostly just chopped apple so it got too filling. 

main course: definitely get the lamb chops or the <mark>Ancho Chile - Honey Glazed Salmon</mark>. both were perfectly cooked and i licked my plates clean. delish!! however, skip the collard greens. they weren't worth the stomach room. but the table next to ours were raving about the brussels sprouts, so i wish i gave those a try. 

dessert: you can not leave the mesa grill without trying the sticky toffee pudding. when i took my first bite the clouds parted, angels were singing, and all the stars aligned. this dessert will go down in the books! yum, yum! 

bottom line: it was a good date night. more misses than hits for me. will i return? maybe if i'm craving some sticky toffee pudding.

i didn't really know much about bobby flay before eating at mesa grill, but left his restaurant with a very high opinion of him. he's not a "celebrity chef" with a tv personality but mediocre culinary skills - he's the real deal. first, the service was impeccable. we were greeted and seated immediately by the hostess and every need we could have had was anticipated and catered to by our waiter and sommellier. second, the setting was very warm and open (this is the type of place where one is made to feel welcome whether he is wearing jeans or a three piece suit). third, and most important, the food was delicious. between my friend and i, we had the <mark>Baby Romaine Salad</mark>, coffee rubbed filet mignon (to die for), new mexican spice rubbed pork tenderloin, mashed potatoes with green chile queso sauce (another favorite), fresh <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>, and toasted coconut layer cake. every bit of the meal was delicious and i truly couldn't have asked for a better dining experience. while this restaurant is a little pricey, it is definitely worth the money and i promise you will leave very satisfied.

my husband and i went to mesa grill for dinner last weekend. besides the bartender who gave me major attitude for asking for sugar free redbull (after pouring 2 guys' to-go cups of beer into rocks glasses for them, i didn't think my request was such a big deal) our experience was great.
mmmm cactus pear margarita. 
the bread basket was really yummy, i actually couldn't stop eating it!!
for starters, i had the sweet potato soup. oh my god. my husband had the tacos and he had food envy for sure. tacos were definitely delicious but tiny!! 3 of them could be eaten in 6 bites or less. the soup was absolutely incredible with the maple cream and marcona almonds...highly recommend.
we shared the <mark>Baby Romaine Salad</mark>, very good and not overdressed. yummy cheese crisp in the middle. 
i had the filet mignon for dinner, perfectly medium rare and very very yummy. spicy chipotle coating, which was not overpowering.
husband had the pork tenderloin - then it was my turn for food envy - wow. extremely delicious, the sauce was to die for.
coconut cake for dessert, skip it. it was totally dry and tasteless. i was very sad because i love coconut cake. eh.
would definitely go back!
as an fyi, most of the recipes that the restaurant uses are in bobby flay's cookbook...i'll be picking that up soon so i can make that soup. mmmmm. i'm still dreaming about it.

i had dinner this evening with my family at the mesa grill, celebrity chef bobby flay's restaurant at  caesar's palace in las vegas. i had made reservations on open table prior to coming to town, but was running late because the traffic on las vegas boulevard was pretty bad. after i pulled into the coliseum valet (which is free, by the way), i told the attendant that i was running late. he pointed out to me where the restaurant is located (it was my first time) and told me that he would call the restaurant to let them know that i was coming. much appreciated! 

it was an early dinner reservation, even though i was late, and the restaurant was about half full when we arrived. by the time dinner ended, however, it seemed like the whole restaurant was full. 

we had lamb porterhouse chops served with two sauces (preserved serrano sauce and mint chimichurri) and a blue <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>, coffee rubbed filet mignon with roasted corn, black angus new york steak strip with mashed potatoes, and <mark>Baby Romaine Salad</mark> with roasted garlic dressing and hominy croutons (how unique). every single entree was cooked perfectly, and each bite was delicious from beginning to end. 

the service at the restaurant was top-notch. we were promptly seated when we arrived (we had reservations), our orders were taken quickly, and our food was delivered to our table within 10 minutes of ordering. our waitress brenda was wonderful, and all of our servers were very attentive. as we left the restaurant, we were greeted by at least half a dozen staff members. 

the food was bit pricey, but well worth the culinary experience. my family and i don't come to vegas often, but i felt that since we were here, we might as well indulge a bit and enjoy ourselves--we certainly did that at mesa grill.

our lunch was 16 <mark>Sixteen Spice Chicken Salad</mark>, <mark>Green Chile Cheeseburger</mark>, <mark>Baby Romaine Salad</mark> and goat cheese queso. thumbs up on all the dishes. one drawback for vegetarians is that they couldn't separate the chicken from the chicken & black bean quesadilla, because they said it was pre-mixed.  peaceful interior, not infused with casino music.

mesa grill is one of my favorites when i go to vegas.  they have awesome food and the servers there are also awesome.  they take the time to go over specials and explain what items on the menu tastes like (on the night i went, it  was super busy). 

drinks:

the servers were raving about their margaritas, but i opted to get a dessert wine and got the weinlaubenhof kracher 08 ($16 per glass), which was very sweet, so if you're into that, must try!

appetizers:

blue corn lobster taco ($20). i basically like corn, so getting this taco was a given. 

<mark>Baby Romaine Salad</mark> ($13), there is nothing that stands out about this salad and tasted generic, so you can save yourself 13 dollars and order something else. 

entrees:

their 22 oz bone in chipotle glazed rib eye ($48) was spot on.  since it was a large piece of meat,  i opted for well done,  but slightly pink.  this turned out to be amazing. the meat was so soft and tender and it held in the juices and flavor very well. also, to top it off the red and green chile sauce pairs perfectly with the slightly smoked taste of the meat. 

mango tuna steak ($38) is a fun little twist to your average steak. it had fun flavors like peppercorn, and pine nuts, cous cous to top off your steak. can't go wrong with a little twist if executed right. 

desserts:

brown butter carrot cake ($11) the cream cheese was so soft and it came with caramelized apples. it wasn't too sweet, but just enough to fulfill a dessert craving.

churros ($11) come topped with cinnamon sugar and chocolate/coconut caramel dipping sauces. the texture of the churro did taste a little hard, but unsure if it was just that day or that's the nature of how the churro is made.

can we just appreciate the perfection that is the tiger prawn tamale? 

for 2 of us, got the tiger prawn tamale to start and a <mark>Spicy Chicken  Sweet Potato Hash</mark> and <mark>Baby Romaine Salad</mark> as entrees. 

as good as the <mark>Spicy Chicken  Sweet Potato Hash</mark> was (imagine a bbq tex mex eggs benedict), we kept wishing we just got more of the tiger prawn tamale. the tamale is very moist and fluffy with a good amount of sweet corn kernels for texture and the prawns were perfectly cooked in a creamy, but not heavy, sauce. 

the hash was quite delicious, but eating half of the dish was sufficient as the bbq spicy sauce + sweet potatoes is a bit too sweet and overwhelming for a brunch dish. salad was a good balance to the hash with fresh lettuce and good dressing.

5 stars for that tamale that haunts my dreams.

sad to say that this was not an enjoyable dinner. we tried many items, and neither the service nor most of the items were even average.
first, there are at least 20 people working in the front of the restaurant, and not once did any of them smile ever. i watched the entire staff and they seemed distant at best.
ok so first the food. ordered nine dishes and only was was any good. blue <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>, chile releno, and cauliflower gratin all underflavored. the sweet potato casserole was marginal.
the <mark>Baby Romaine Salad</mark> was described to have <mark>Spicy Chorizo Sausage</mark>. only one dime sized slice appeared on the plate.
the lobster tacos were fantastic, although a very small portion for almost 20 bucks.
we arrived 20 minutes early for our reservation and the manager was reluctant to seat us even though the place was half empty. he originally said we'd have to wait until closer to the reservation time.
i came here 2 years ago and had a great dinner. (see prior review.) not sure what happened but it looks like the place is more touristy.
sad to have had this experience.

i had lunch here the other day and it was so good we went back for dinner tonight. dinner was even better! service is top notch and the food was amazing. for lunch we had <mark>Baby Romaine Salad</mark> with chorizo and homily croutons, <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark>, and the best burger ever. for dinner we had salmon, <mark>Sophie's Chopped Salad</mark>, incredible pork tenderloin and cauliflower gratin. both times we sat at the bar and the service was great. every time i travel to vegas i go to mesa grill. highly recommend.

i was excited to eat here, due to all the hype of the restaurant.  as i had saturday brunch here, reservations were no problem.  the food is tasty. i admit.  i had the <mark>Smoked Salmon Quesadilla</mark>, with salmon roe for appetizers and <mark>Spicy Scrambled Eggs</mark> with jalapenos and ham.  my only complaint was that they couldn't make my eggs with all egg whites or egg substitute, as the waiter said that the chef would not do it. i would assume that they would try to accommodate with my request, but they didn't. i guess customer satisfaction is not a top priority here.

after being told that if everyone in our party didnt show up for our reservation, we would be charged $50/person penalty (wtf!!), we all showed up on time to find the place half empty (for saturday brunch).  they should have been kissing the floor we walked for our business...jeez.

anyways, onto the pros:
- white peach margarita: not too sweet, but still very tasty.  nice and tart
- bread basket: the best bread basket i've ever had.  complete with blue corn muffins, blueberry <mark>Coffee</mark>, jalapeno cheddar scones, tequila scones, and some other really yummy scone thing.  they gave us plenty of each so everyone in my group had a taste of everything.
- egg chilaquiles: i think i misunderstood what these are supposed to be, but regardless, the dish was amazing!  think <mark>Spicy Scrambled Eggs</mark> on top of corn tostadas which were layered with white cheddar.  everything was covered in this delicious green sauce.  the sauce was soo flavorful, i couldnt stop eating even though i was wayy to full from the bread basket and appetizer.

cons:
- goat cheese fundido:  well, not a con cause it was gooood. but nothing special.  
- i had seen this mushroom quesadilla appetizer on their lunch menu online, but since we were there for brunch, they only had these other <mark>Smoked Salmon Quesadilla</mark>.  i asked them if they could make me a mushroom one, and they refused saying that the ingredients wouldnt have been prepared.  maybe i'm naive about these things, but um it was 12:30...and they had all the quesadilla fixings put together for brunch anway...just add the mushrooms!!  i'm paying enough to deserve a little more flexibility.  again, shows you how puffed up they are.

all in all, the bread basket and the chilaquiles make up for not giving me a mushroom quesadilla.

i love this place! things i'm in love with here.... <mark>Smoked Salmon Quesadilla</mark>, ahi tuna nachos, and the salad with goat cheese in it. as a native texan, i'm pretty picky about margaritas and the ones here more than pass the test... no nasty slushies here folks. oh, and have to throw in that lunch is pretty reasonably priced for gourmet dining. lunch for 2 will throw you back $50, but it's definitely $50 well spent!

maybe brunch isn't the best way to sample flay's menu, because i left thoroughly unimpressed. my party split the crispy bacon and <mark>Smoked Salmon Quesadilla</mark>, both of which were incredibly ordinary. the waiter (more on him in a bit) strongly recommended the spicy chicken + <mark>Spicy Chicken  Sweet Potato Hash</mark>, which i would only recommend if you like eating baby food. while the presentation and flavors were all there, the hash was more of a mash and when you combine that with really tender chicken, you get mush. the creamy grits were a winner, but i really regret pairing that with the mushy chicken/hash. a little bit of textural contrast may have made this good. well, at least i left full.

good service might have made this a better experience, but the waiter was too much of a salesman. i'm not sure i've ever had a waiter try to push certain dishes so hard, it seemed as if he wanted to order our meals for us. from this single sampling, i'd say that mesa grill does not live up to the bobby flay hype.

my fiance and i went for sunday brunch and had a fabulous meal. we both loved our <mark>Smoked Salmon Quesadilla</mark> appetizer. my fiance had the chilequiles while i had the chicken & <mark>Spicy Chicken  Sweet Potato Hash</mark> (think southwestern eggs benedict). they were ab-fab, as were the <mark>Spicy Mango - Glazed Bacon</mark> and chorizo we ordered as sides; the bacon, in particular is insanely delicious. 

the restaurant was smaller than expected, but the decor is lovely. our seats afforded us a view of the open kitchen as well as the casino floor, so we could people watch as well as watch food being prepared. 

please note, if you are looking for taco bell, on the border, etc. look elsewhere, that isn't the kind of food served here.

this review is based just on the weekend brunch.
for me, this was one of those spots where it was really good the first time but was ehhhhh the next time. 

food: plenty of great choices on bobby flay's brunch menu. the food has high-end chef written all over it.. small servings, high-priced, but amazing flavor.
as you are seated, you are given a basket of different breads and muffins that are super tasty and different.
the yelp popular <mark>Smoked Salmon Quesadilla</mark> is fantastic. at first glance, it looks like a simple dish that's bound to disappoint but no, this is some quality smoked salmon on top of a well-grilled quesadilla. 
the chilaquiles is okay.. nothing special and was kind of cold. 
the <mark>Spicy Chicken  Sweet Potato Hash</mark> was pretty good. loved the hollandaise sauce on it.

ambiance: a colorful, classy restaurant with a wide-open space and views of the casino on one side and the kitchen staff doing their art on the other. located in front of the giant sportsbook/pokerroom area of caesars, this is a pretty restaurant with lots of appeal just from the outside. a good place for a social brunch whether you're with your significant or with a group of friends. 

service: servers are very professional and friendly. they come by our table frequently to check on us. the food takes a lonnnngggg time to be served. i don't know if it's because they take their time to cook the food perfectly but the restaurant wasn't crazy busy and it was a bit of a wait.

tips: if you're here for brunch, you have to try the <mark>Smoked Salmon Quesadilla</mark>. come earlier for brunch because the restaurant tends to get very busy during the peak of lunch.

this place is a family favorite for us, especially for brunch! we have tried pretty much everything on the menu with few disappointments. prices are very reasonable for being on the strip. <mark>Cactus Pear Iced Tea</mark> is a must; i probably go through a whole pitcher :p 
for shared appetizer we like the rough cut tuna nachos (basically a poke), queso fundido, and for something different the <mark>Smoked Salmon Quesadilla</mark>.  bread basket is a treat with both sweet and savory muffins, scones, biscuits, and bread. for entrees we usually stick to hot dishes - <mark>Spicy Chicken  Sweet Potato Hash</mark>, chilequiles, salmon. grits and the bacon are favorite sides. i'd say skip the <mark>New Mexican Spiced Pork Tenderloin Sandwich</mark> (cold deli style), and the salads unless that's what you are in the mood for. steak and eggs is a make your own taco dish which is huge, more than enough for one person. salmon is another great treat! also note that you can only get the churros at dinner time for dessert.

overall, i was disappointed by this iron chef america restaurant.  

just so everyone has full information, i do not like bobby flay.  on iron chef he is so cocky, and i bet you nine times out of ten, his dishes will consist of the secret ingredient plus some blended sauce made of tomatillos and habaneros.  but, i have also watched his throwdown show, and people seem to like his food.  and the guy looks like he can grill up some mean meat.  so i was excited to try his restaurant.         

on to the review:

my friend made the reservation for six people and they took her credit card down because if you're late or miss the reservation, they will charge you $50 per person!  needless to say, we were on time.

bread basket:  the free bread basket they bring you at the start of the meal was really good.  it is an assortment of muffins, coffee cake, and breads.  i must say that the jalapeno cheddar bread was damn good.     

appetizers:  the rough cut tuna nachos were good, but small portions.  7 tiny chips to be exact.  i know because after each of us only took one chip, there was only one left on the plate.  the fish was fresh and tasty, but the sauce may have been a little bit too sweet for me.  the bacon and <mark>Crispy Bacon  Hash Brown Quesadilla</mark> was nothing special.

entrees:  i though bobby flay, have to get a meat dish, right?  so my friend and i both ordered the <mark>New Mexican Spiced Pork Tenderloin Sandwich</mark>.  i wouldn't order it again.  the sandwich was dry and just didn't do anything for me.  very little pork for such thick bread.  french fries were good with a nice little spice to them.  the steak tartar was good, the best entree in my opinion.  the spicy chicken and <mark>Spicy Chicken  Sweet Potato Hash</mark> was just weird tasting.  i did not like it all, but maybe that's just my tastes.  the egg and steak dish was bleh....steak, eggs, tortilla, salsa, sour cream, and guacamole, it wasn't baaad per se, just not great.  my other friend ordered the spicy egg dish which i did not try because i don't particularly care for goat cheese, however, the ham that came with it was pretty good, but not spectacular.  

dessert:  we got the chocolate cake, which was good, but i've had way better at other places.  nothing transcendent here.  

everyone in my group felt the same way about the food...disappointing.  i wouldn't return back there to eat.  our waiter was really good, and the decor is nice inside.  (but isn't the decor nice in all vegas hotel restaurants?)  i would give it 2 1/2 if we could give 1/2s.  my advice:  skip it (at least for brunch).

this place is not that unreasonably priced compared to some of the other big name restaurants in vegas, we had a brunch there and the average entree ran between 10-20 bucks. i had the <mark>Spicy Scrambled Eggs</mark> with goat cheese, jalapeno, and chives with apricot glazed ham and buttermilk biscuit. it was some of the best <mark>Spicy Scrambled Eggs</mark> i've ever had. we also shared the goat cheese queso and the egg and <mark>Crispy Bacon  Hash Brown Quesadilla</mark>. yummmmmmmmm. excellent brunch spot and you really could tell bobby flay had a hand in the whole menu.

i had brunch here on a weekend (they only serve the lunch menu m-f). 

maybe my experience wasn't so great because my options were limited- but overall- this place was a huge disappointment. 

i ordered the <mark>Cactus Pear Iced Tea</mark>- nothing too special about it. 

we had the goat cheese appetizer that everyone is always raving about and it was nothing more than melted goat cheese with some peppers in it which tasted average. it was so rich we only ate about 25% of it. 

my husband ordered a breakfast enchilada and i ordered the bacon and <mark>Crispy Bacon  Hash Brown Quesadilla</mark> (off the appetizer side of the menu). in both items, the tortilla was too hard, undercooked, and heavy tasting. my husband's food tasted no different than normal breakfast food (just eggs and chorizo inside). mine was disgusting- too much goat cheese grilled on the top, not enough bacon inside (hardly any) and the hash brown with the tortillas didn't taste right at all (bad combination but i thought it might taste ok). 

my experience has been that all of the newer places in vegas have tasted great- because they are still establishing themselves. the other places that have been around for a while no longer care to maintain themselves and have been mediocre to disappointing. the only exception to that has been nobu.

i wish we would have gone to mon ami gabi or one of the high end buffets at bellagio or the wynn instead- it would have cost the same and no doubt tasted better!

i have been a fan of bobby flay since catching him on "iron chef" and 
"throwdown" but never really thought i would eat in his restaurant. my 
boyfriend really wanted to go because he said that a friend told him that the burgers were amazing. i'm not a fan of burgers but i did find items on the menu that i would enjoy. we walked in for saturday brunch and had an amazing server. she was very sweet and informative. we decided to order the salmon and tuna tartares for an appetizer. it was incredible. the flavors worked perfect together and had just a little bit of spice. 

for entrees, my boyfriend ordered the buffalo burger with south-west
french fries and i ordered the bacon and <mark>Crispy Bacon  Hash Brown Quesadilla</mark> that 
came with an egg and salsa on top. he enjoyed his burger and i loved
my entree. i don't have any complaints. anything that combines bacon,
hash browns, and eggs is wonderful to me. 

i would also recommend ordering a cactus pear margarita. i've never
had anything like it before. i also wanted to try the peach margarita, but
didn't want to spend the extra money. the restaurant is a bit on the pricey side but that's to be expected of a restaurant owned by one of 
the food network's most popular chefs. 

i would def go back next time i'm in vegas.

bobby flay, you did me good. 

i was excited to try mesa grill and hoping to get a glimpse of bobby flay. i went with my bf, friend and her bf on a sunday for brunch. we walked in and were quickly greeted by two hostess with bright colored shirts and black suits on. the place was very colorful with one wall with a rainbow of agua de fresca jugs. we sat in the middle area, where the boys could still see the games going on on the other side of the glass wall in the sports bet area. our waiter was nice yet cocky like bobby flay, which almost rubbed me the wrong way. after a heavy night of drinking, i wasn't in the mood for any more alcohol, even though the bellini sounded good! i ordered the cactus pear ice tea ($4). the ice tea had a southern tea feel, slightly flowery. i believe it comes with some simple syrup that you could put in it, but i think it tastes better without it. 

bf: do you have any regular ice tea? 
waiter: no 
=( 

we were brought a basket of 4 different kinds of bread. jalapeno muffin, regular corn bread, jalapeno scone and coffee cake. the jalapeno muffin was a perfectly buttery, light, and flakey and had tiny bright green flakes of jalapenos so it had a kick of heat, but not too hot where it burned your mouth. the regular corn bread had specks of red and green chile flakes, and perfectly baked where it was still moist. the scone had a hint of sweet taste with some dried raisins and cranberries. the coffee cake wasn't too sweet, where you really needed to drink it with coffee. 

as per suggestion by the waiter, we ordered the appetizer crispy bacon + <mark>Crispy Bacon  Hash Brown Quesadilla</mark> with fried egg and spicy tomato salsa. this was so good. the tortilla tasted homemade, where it was light and fluffy and not chewy. the bacon gave it the saltyness and the hashbrown a slight crisp. all together with the fried egg and salsa on top... yum 


the waiter suggested the <mark>Ancho Chile - Honey Glazed Salmon</mark> with spicy black bean sauce and roasted jalapeno crema as the perfect dish to display bobby flays style of balancing sweet and savory so i wanted to get it. i was instructed to make sure to eat the salmon with the white sauce. the salmon was perfectly cooked where it was flaky and just fell apart while still being moist. the sauces were so bright and the colors were vibrant. it had a nice fresh salsa on top. all together it was nice. i had expected a bit more of fire in bobby flays dish, but it was just enough that you could appreciate all the flavors. 

<mark>Spicy Scrambled Eggs</mark> (green onion, jalapeno, goat cheese) apricot-mustard glazed ham+ buttermilk biscuits. wow! you'd think "what, its just <mark>Spicy Scrambled Eggs</mark>" but the <mark>Spicy Scrambled Eggs</mark> were delicious! i swear i love goat cheese. it was creamy and salty and hearty. the ham was sweet and salty and makes your mouth water. the biscuits were a bit spicy like it had a bunch of black pepper in it and buttery at the same time. great dish! 

you could get a side of creamy grits or homestyle fries with the egg dishes. wow these grits were so freakin good. i think they had goat cheese in them as well. so creamy and tasty. 

my friend and her bf both got the scrambled egg enchilada. they said it was good. 

overall i was very pleased with mesa grill. his dishes werent as spicy as i had expected, as hes always bringing in the heat, but everything had a nice balance of heat that you could still taste the flavors of the dishes. yeah bobby!

i still think chef bobby flay is a total d bag but his food is so damn good!  

after a long flight into vegas our first stop was to go to the mesa grill for lunch.  this was our first meal of the day and we were starving.  we had a short wait of about 15 minutes but had a drink while we waited.  our server greeted right away and his assistant brought us water and assortment of bread.  first of all the bread was really good.  there was a combination of mini bite size jalapeno cheese biscuit, blue corn and yellow corn bread (the best corn bread i've ever had) and two fruit type of pastry bars.  

for the appetizers we had the <mark>Tiger Shrimp  Roasted Garlic Corn Tamale</mark> and a <mark>Crispy Bacon  Hash Brown Quesadilla</mark> topped with a over easy egg.  both were outstanding.  my wife had the chillaquilles and i had the burger.  both entrees were delicious and so flavorful.  

service was on par and the atmosphere was great.  highly recommend checking out mesa grill!

:o)!!!!

bobby flay.... you son of a bitch...... here i am, thinking that you're some asshole that's famous based on your looks and cockiness.  boy was i wrong.  you made me eat my words and boy were those words delicious!

ladies and gentleman.... this man knows how to cook!  i walked in here thinking that it was all hype, but the four of us were highly impressed with all our dishes and bread basket.

the food:
bread basket - there was a good mixture of sweet and savory breads.  i should have taken notes but some of the stand outs were the coffee cake, corn bread, and what we named the jalapeno cheese "popper", so basically all the breads they were offering.
